title: Aspirin Synthesis
description: Learn how to synthesize acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin) from salicylic acid and acetic anhydride. This experiment demonstrates esterification reactions and purification techniques.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Reagents
stepDetails.description: Measure 2.0g of salicylic acid and place in a dry 125mL Erlenmeyer flask. Add 5mL of acetic anhydride using a graduated cylinder.

stepDetails.title: Add Catalyst
stepDetails.description: Carefully add 2-3 drops of concentrated phosphoric acid (H₃PO₄) as a catalyst. Swirl gently to mix the contents.

stepDetails.title: Heat Reaction Mixture
stepDetails.description: Heat the flask in a water bath at 85°C for 15 minutes. Monitor the temperature carefully and observe the formation of acetylsalicylic acid.

stepDetails.title: Cool and Add Water
stepDetails.description: Remove from heat and allow to cool for 5 minutes. Slowly add 20mL of distilled water while stirring to precipitate the product.

stepDetails.title: Filter Product
stepDetails.description: Filter the precipitated aspirin using vacuum filtration. Wash the crystals with cold distilled water.

stepDetails.title: Dry Product
stepDetails.description: Transfer the filtered crystals to a watch glass and allow to air dry, or place in a drying oven at 60°C.

stepDetails.title: Weigh and Calculate Yield
stepDetails.description: Weigh the dry aspirin crystals and calculate the theoretical and percent yield of the reaction.

stepDetails.title: Purity Test
stepDetails.description: Perform a melting point determination to assess the purity of your synthesized aspirin.

safetyInfo: This virtual experiment simulates real laboratory conditions. Please review safety protocols and understand the procedures before starting. Always wear proper PPE in real laboratory settings. Acetic anhydride and phosphoric acid are corrosive chemicals.

title: Acid-Base Titration
description: Determine the concentration of an unknown acid solution using a standard base solution. Master the art of precise measurements and endpoint detection.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Equipment
stepDetails.description: Set up the burette in the stand and rinse with distilled water, then with the NaOH solution. Fill the burette with 0.1M NaOH solution.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Sample
stepDetails.description: Transfer exactly 25.0mL of the unknown HCl solution into a clean conical flask.

stepDetails.title: Add Indicator
stepDetails.description: Add 2-3 drops of phenolphthalein indicator to the acid solution in the conical flask. Place on white tile for better endpoint visibility.

stepDetails.title: Initial Titration
stepDetails.description: Record the initial burette reading. Begin titrating by adding NaOH solution slowly while swirling the flask continuously.

stepDetails.title: Identify Endpoint
stepDetails.description: Continue adding NaOH drop by drop near the endpoint. The endpoint is reached when the solution turns permanently pale pink.

stepDetails.title: Calculate Concentration
stepDetails.description: Record the final burette reading and calculate the volume of NaOH used. Use the formula to determine the concentration of the HCl solution.

safetyInfo: Handle all chemicals with care. NaOH is caustic and can cause burns. HCl is corrosive. Always wear safety goggles and handle glassware carefully. Work in a well-ventilated area.
